Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2008 08:30PM embmom wrote: Emma--I know how you are feeling--I am right there with you--we seem to be at about the same point in this crappy little journey--please know that you are in my thoughts--the ladies on this board are amazing--take their strength with you when you go for your biopsy--I know that I was thinking about all their stories of courage when I was trying to distract myself during the ultrasound today--About  dealing with the anxiety--I did find a upside to it today--when I put on a new pair of pants to wear to the doctor they about fell off--I have hardly eaten anything for about 3 weeks--is this the diet I have been waiting for?  Seriously tho--take time to be REALLY good to yourself--know that you are in our thoughts!
Posts.Title: fear of possible bc diagnosis Emma56 Emma56

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2008 05:43PM - edited Feb 17, 2008 05:43PM by embmom
Posts.Title: fear of possible bc diagnosis Emma56 Emma56

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2008 05:43PM embmom wrote: Emma--I just read that you are afraid of IBC because of certain symtoms--I think I might know what you are talking about--is your skin red like a rash just at a certain area of your breast--like right on top of where the lump is--is it really sore?  That's what mine looks like and I was scared to death of IBC--the dr told me that the area is inflammed because the tumor is actually right under the skin--she told me she didn't want to use the term inflammed because she didn't want me to think it was IBC--she told me that IBC will cause your entire breast to turn pink--She said that the fact that my breast was red and inflammed was a sign of malignancy..but she also told me that a couple of months of chemo should shrink the mass right down so that when they do the mastectomy the lump would be smaller--she said that having the chemo early lets them really keep an eye on how well the chemo is doing.  My breast is very sore so even tho I don 't know how in the world I am going to cope with chemo I know that I need to have this addressed pretty quickly.  Good luck--life just sucks sometimes, doesn't it?  PS--I was just reading somewhere that some of the cancer societies have support coaches that can help you--maybe you could call a local women's center or cancer society and see if there was someone there that could help you.  My son's best friend's mom is a bc survivor of several years and he told me she works with womens support groups all the time--the kids found out last night and he told me she would be callling me first thing monday to talk...the guilt and shame are hard to get past...I have told a couple of people this weekend and the kids and when they asked for details I just said they found it on a mammogram a couple of weeks ago and the rest of the details we are keeping private..I did say to the kids cause they really pushed that maybe there were some "what ifs?" involved but that the dr. said now is now and that's it.. they didn't push any more..The fear is the worst part and having the guilt and shame on top just make it pure hell--but I have been trying to handle each step at a time--that's what these ladies keep saying--I am only trying to concentrate on the biopsy this week--it's not easy and I haven't been real successful but I just keep tellling myself that this is enough to handle right now..You know something else strange?  I didn't seek help out of fear but each time I have gone thru one of the steps it really hasn't been that bad--I hadn't been to a doctor in years so I had to go to a stranger with this and it really wasn't all that bad--the mammo wasn't bad--the surgeon was wonderful--the ultrasound was easy--I'm not saying I wasn't scared poopless but I got thru them and you can to--you just will--and maybe it isn't bc after all--I will keep you in my thoughts--embmom
Posts.Title: fear of possible bc diagnosis Emma56 Emma56

Posts.Content: embmom wrote: First of all let me thank everyone of you out there that helped me thru this--I couldn't have done it without your support and good wishes.  I saw the surgeon--she was the sweetest woman!  She said we are just going to deal with Now--now--not what was in the past--She looked my breast which is by now red and a little inflammed (but its not IBC)just the tumor has gotten very close to the skin and said that after doing the ultrasound (which was done right in the office that we are probably looking at stage 2 (because some of the lymph nodes were a little enlarged)--she is pretty sure it is cancer.  I go for a biopsy next week at the breast center where she is located. Her plan right now is for me to see an oncologist and start a 3-4 month chemo followed by a mastectomy.  She expained that this is really effective because they can actually tell if the chemo they are using is working because they can watch the tumors get smaller.  But the only thing  that I am going to be thinking about his weekend is  the biopsy and that's a pretty much foregone conclusion. We'll  tell our three grown sons this weekend and it will be hard-but men being boys they just want to know will mom still be mom and will I be ok--the details of my "woman's parts" they haven't ever been very interested in especially the details of my hot flashes thru menopause--just do what you need to with the heat or the AC mom--I spoke to my sister--she lives pretty far away but said she could be here as soon as I needed her--this weight that has lifted off my shoulders was 100 times what this little bc thing weighed!  The doctor was so sweet and positive--and I think she knew I was prepared for the absolute worst--when I left she said--'Don't spend all your money yet!" funny I had been thinking along those lines last week..Thanks again you all!  Dx 1/2008, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: New here is back from the surgeon embmom Sassa

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2008 05:08AM embmom wrote: Thanks for all your replies--I'll guess I'll just have to wait and see what happens.  So far I am on #11 and am not noticing any skin changes.  They have told me I don't need to put any cream on yet--they will tell me when..funny how every place is different.  Oh well..I'll just hope for the best.  The physicist did tell me the first day that it might get so bad they have to stop but the rad onc didn't seem to be concerned at all..Thanks and good wishes to you all.
Posts.Title: Anyone use BOLUS embmom EmilyJane

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2008 06:21PM embmom wrote: Thanks for your replies--the one they are using on me looks like a soft piece of brass fabric.  It sure is cold when they put it on!  I finished up chemo in June 08 and had surgery in July--a L mast with no reconstruction as yet.  I did fine during chemo --worked everyday and was working in less than a week after surgery.  I am starting to notice some fatigue but part of that might be that my appt  time is 7:10 in the am. and I am a night person so its hard to get up so early.  Bad as it is tho it does mean that I am the 2nd appt and I am usually back home in less than 20 min. Good luck to you both!
Posts.Title: Anyone use BOLUS embmom EmilyJane

Posts.Content: embmom wrote: They are using the BOLUS mat on me everyday because my cancer had invaded the skin.  They said I would burn worse than someone who didn't use it.  Anyone out there who has used the BOLUS--what shape was your skin in during and after treatment?  When I ask the doc all they say is it will get red and that everyone is different.  Also did it effect the amount of fatigue you had.  Thanks!  ( 7 down--23 to go!) Dx 1/2008, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Anyone use BOLUS embmom EmilyJane

Posts.Content: May 1, 2015 06:26PM embmom wrote: It will be 3 years in May from diagnosis and treatment for a brain met. Treatment was surgery and stereotactic radiation. Worked thru everything..own my own business, no choice. My onc and I have decided no more scans, after 2 years of regular scans, unless I have symptoms. Good luck
Posts.Title: Survival after detection of brain mets? MarshaMay embmom

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2008 07:23PM embmom wrote: Hey everyone--I'm due to start either this week or next--I've had the prelim pix done so they tell me they make a plan, then call to get started.  I have 30 tx, underarm up to the suclavicle or whatever they call it.  My chest area is REAL nice to look at these days--sharpie x's covered with clear tape all over, a big incision line thru the middle where the left boob used to be (my nurse sister said its not a scar--its an incision line) and yucky steri-strips and a very bruised right boob from having the port removed.  Anyway, after almost 9 months of tests, scans, chemo, and surgery I'm ready for all this to be over!
Posts.Title: SEPTEMBER 2008 rads group NancyD NancyD

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2008 02:22PM embmom wrote: They are also using the BOLUS on me for every treatment--the one they use is like a very thin piece of brass fabric.  The way they explained it to me is that it will bring the rads closer to the surface so that in my case it will fry more of the skin that the cancer had spread to.  I am on 15 out of 30 and barely notice any difference as yet.  I am starting to notice the fatigue tho.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: SEPTEMBER 2008 rads group NancyD NancyD

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2008 05:08PM embmom wrote: Thanks for all the encouragement--what a whiner I am!  I just finished reading about Annie's situation over on the TripNeg board--now that's something to cry about.  Anyway, I'll quit worrying about my stupid hair and direct all my energy to sending good thoughts to those of you who are trying to fight this crappy disease-- only to have it pop up somewhere else.   Embmom.
Posts.Title: SEPTEMBER 2008 rads group NancyD NancyD

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2008 03:45PM embmom wrote: Nancy--I did the first of my 5 boosts today--I wondered how you got out of them--anyway they took all of 27 seconds--I counted--I didn't even have to take my shirt all the way off.  I wish they could just zap me for 125 seconds and be done with it.  Getting up at 6:30 in the morning to be over there for 30 seconds is tough...but it'll all be over before we know it!!! Yeh!!! Embmom
Posts.Title: SEPTEMBER 2008 rads group NancyD NancyD

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2008 11:50AM embmom wrote: It's funny how each place is different..at the rads center I go to for the rads treatments you just walk into the room and take your shirt off--we have 3 females and 1 male tech and altho I am getting used to it it is a little strange feeling..you then walk over to the table and lay your shirt across your chest and then they start moving you around and marking you up..sometimes the sharpie marks they have used need to be redone.  Then they use the Bolus on me and use my shirt- which sometimes falls off during treatment- to cover my good side.  I understand that it would take more time to put on those paper things so I just go with the flow and hope its over soon.
Posts.Title: SEPTEMBER 2008 rads group NancyD NancyD

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2008 04:35PM embmom wrote: I finished with rads on the 13th of Oct. and just this week the huge blistering oozing mess from the boosts has healed.  The rad doc said it was very slow to heal..it was really very painful..partly from the soreness of the skin and from the muscle damage below it. I tried the silvadene cream as directed and broke out in hives which are just now clearing up.  It seems in addition to the other drug allergies I have I can now add sulpha.  Everyone else seemed to be doing so well I thought I was the only one with lingering skin issues.  But take heart if will finally clear up..I now have just a big crusty (but dry crusty) area on my chest and it doesn't hurt anymore..you will get there soon.  Good luck--Embmom
Posts.Title: SEPTEMBER 2008 rads group NancyD NancyD

Posts.Content: May 28, 2012 11:10AM embmom wrote: thanks for the encouraging words!  They really help!  MK
Posts.Title: brain mets embmom banjobanjo

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2008 12:40PM - edited Sep 18, 2008 12:41PM by embmom Dancemom--Its ok to be upset about any of this--it isn't easy.  People say that rads are a "walk in the park" compared to chemo and sometimes I wonder what park they walk in--none of this is easy or pleasant or a piece of cake...but..it is doable and necessary and we should be thankful they have the treatments they do for our cancer.  I was waiting for my rad appt the other day and the man behind me had lung cancer with mets to the brain and spine--he's got problems---The process of the radation is what gets me down--lying on the table kinda exposed is really upsetting--more so than the chemo (I took the ativan for chemo and just kinda enjoyed being in lala land for a few hours).  Sometimes we just need to let it all out and not try to be so brave for everyone to the point where it just builds up and then we lose it.  Do something extra nice for yourself these days..make that your treat for doing this..I had a manicure the other day just because...This will be over soon and then we can get on with the rest of our lives.. Take care and good wishes to you..Embmom
Posts.Title: SEPTEMBER 2008 rads group NancyD NancyD

Posts.Content: embmom wrote: My dh just called me here thinking I am working--I own my own little store and am known to work crazy hours and I told him I would be home soon--really I am sitting here like I have done every night for weeks pouring over all your wonderful posts.  I had a diagnostic mammogram last week that showed a 5cm mass in my left breast that I have known about for over a year. When I first found it it was so small and easy to forget about. The shame and guilt of letting this happen has been the worst part of this situation. I'm an intelligent woman--I see all the info about early detection--  My dh knows I didn't seek help and he knows it was for a vaiety of reasons--mostly I just didn't want to be sick--Depression and anxiety are things I fight my hardest against everyday and for the most part I just couldn't feel well enough to start a battle such as this. I know I have hurt him by hiding this from him--when I told him finally we had to talk he thought I wanted a divorce because I had been so distant for so long--I couldn't risk him feeling it. I have a surgeons appt. on Friday and will go, but I feel so stupid that this has happened.  The internist said not to worry about those feelings--just deal with now--but I am so worried that my grown children will be so hurt by this..they all know people whose moms have dealt with breast cancer and are doing fine now--and their mom isn't going to be that lucky.  I'm sorry if I bored anyone with my story but my dh and I have decided not to give many details of this illness-he knows how ashamed I am-it seems like sometimes people want so much info--I guess I just needed someone to talk to about this.  I just don't want anyone else to know how long I waited to seek help.  One of my best friends was dx in Sept and is having an awful time just recovering from rad.. and she sought treatment early for a very small lump.. I don't know how I am going to deal with all this now--I know that I won't be able to keep my business going if I am sick all the time..I don't know how I am going to tell my kids and my sisters...My mom had bc when I was in high school and I can still remember the day I came home from school and saw her crying--she had the mast. that was what they did in the 70's and no reoccurrence for 25 years only to have it pop up in her stomach--she died 8 years ago.  Thanks for at least letting me write this down even if no one reads it--your posts give me hope and were what eventually made me go to the dr.  Thanks!  Dx 1/2008, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: New here embmom BarbaraS

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2008 10:05AM embmom wrote: Congrats on finishing Nancy!  We have both been doing this for about the same time and it seems like forever!  Yesterday I had kind of a meltdown and skipped the rad appt.  My dh drove me over as usual but I was so upset about everything and especially my hair that I put my foot down and just couldn't go in.  I guess I just had to have some control back over something.  I ended up walking back the 2 1/2 miles back home from the center at 7:30 in the morning and I had forgotten my hat so I was cold and angry!  Anyway by the time I got home and cried for a bit I called the doc and explained to her what happened.  She said she understood and just to come in today which is what I did.  Thankfully the techs didn't say anything.  They had called yesterday and I said I wasn't feeling well.  Anyway I only have the five boosts to go and then I'm done.  I am really upset about my hair tho..it's been since mid June when I had my last chemo and I barely have more than just long fuzzies..no real hair.  I have some social stuff coming up in the nest 2 weeks and I am just really upset.  I just can't wear the wig anymore.. I have been wearing this stupid ball cap--I've never worn one before in my life--anyway enough whining--I asked the doc if she ever had anyone not get their hair back and she said no--but I keep thinking maybe I did something wrong and it's not coming back..anyway I'm all done next Wed. and I have a great trip to Florida this weekend with friends to take me away from this for at least a couple of days.  Thanks for letting me whine...Godd thoughts and wishes to you all.  Embmom
Posts.Title: SEPTEMBER 2008 rads group NancyD NancyD

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2014 09:38PM embmom wrote: I am a stage 4 who is classified as stage 4 NED on my chart.  My onc uses the NED term. I am also not undergoing any treatment at this time.  I think that it depends on what your situation is as to whether you continue to undergo any form of treatment.  I had a single brain met 2 years ago that was triple neg.  After a craniotomy and SRT  there were no further treatment options for me.  We just wait and see what happens.  Sometimes it would be nice to know that I was taking something that might prevent more mets, but there really isn't anything to take.  That is the situation with many trip. neg cases.
Posts.Title: thoughts about difference between remission and NED reader123 leftfootforward

Posts.Content: embmom wrote: Can't believe I'm writing this..I'm just home from the hospital.  I was taken by lifesquad after a seizure Friday night.  I had been having balance issues on my left side for a couple of weeks and going to call the onc after my son's wedding on the 9th. I found out I have 1 met that is on a cyst on my right parietal node.  After the MRI they said only met in the brain. I will call the oncs office on Tuesday to set up the rest of the tests.  As a triple negative 4 years out, even my onc told me over a year ago that I had beaten the cancer and that it was hihly unlikely it would return.  Oh,well.I have lots going one next  few weeks--joyful and not joyful.  I also have decisions to make abut my busy fourishing business.  I had a wonderful 4ears and accomplished alot.  I am trying to remain as positive for the future, whatever it holds for me.  Thanks for being here.  Mary Kay Dx 1/2008, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: brain mets embmom banjobanjo

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2008 10:23PM embmom wrote: Thanks so much for your reply--my dh has been so nice but I know he is so hurt--I was really afraid that someone would write back about my being so stupid--I know I deserve it. Right now I am trying to take each step one at a time--I have learned this from reading all the posts--My appt. is on Fri. with a really good breast surgeon at a breast center.. thank you again for your kind words--they really helped.
Posts.Title: New here embmom BarbaraS

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2017 06:38PM embmom wrote: I finally feel better! After about passing out on Tuesday, I went to the onc's office and got a bag of fluids. I was starting to get dehydrated. A bag of fluids and some extra anti nausea meds and I am back to my old self! They told me not to wait so long the next time! Next time as soon as the nausea starts I am going over to the office, I really didn't have this issue the first time so this was new for me. I also do have to do the neulasta because my counts this time were low and even stayed a little low with the neulasta. This is a result of chemo second time around. It is nice to have a place to vent!
Posts.Title: Taxotere and carboplatin a second time around embmom Groovywilma

Posts.Content: embmom wrote: Ten years ago I went thru taxotere and carboplatin for left breast stage 3 triple negative. After a met to the brain, and radiation 4 years late,I had 5 great years. Now here I am with right breast her2 positive. I just did the first treatment of tchp with neulasta last wed and it has totally wiped me out. I don't see an end to this nausea even with compazine or zofran. The diarrhea has been manageable at least. The first time around the chemo was bad but after a not so bad 3rd day I was able to continue working...a little slower maybe. Now I can't even get out of bed....is this a result of the TC twice or just the combo of the other drugs with it. I don't see doing this 5 more times. Thanks for listening. Dx 1/2008, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Taxotere and carboplatin a second time around embmom Groovywilma

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2017 04:04AM embmom wrote: Notverybrave, I will see the onc on Wed. And he will let me know what we'll do. The breast surgeon,tho, told me that it would be the taxol or something similar and the herceptin. No carbo this time as I had it last time. I also have been reading about perjeta. My tumor is 2.5 cm so I am already stage 2 and from reading it seems like I might get that, too. Tues. I do scans all day to see if either of the cancers have spread. I have been Ned for 5 years! I can't believe my luck getting the 2 most aggressive cancers! At least this new one has more treatment options than the trip neg. this one is er- and pr+ her+".Thanks for responding! How are you doing?
Posts.Title: Stage 4 triple neg now her+ new primary embmom MommyErin

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2008 11:57AM embmom wrote: Thanks again for all your kind words..there is just something about being able to talk to people who are actually going thru this...the term that was used in the Dr. Love book was "neglected primary" it referred to those tumors that were large as a result of someone not being able as a result of fear to seek medical attention.  Anyway you all are great and thanks for the encouraging words about chemo--I know things are different for everyone but if I know that at least going into all this I will still have my little business, it will be a little easier--I have great customers--and many have already expressed a desire to help and I think being around their upbeat attitudes and keeping busy will be good for me even if its at a much slower pace than before.
Posts.Title: just back from the biopsy embmom HeatherBLocklear

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2008 02:43PM embmom wrote: Thanks you again for all your kind words--I will let you all know what the surgeon tells me tomorrow.
Posts.Title: New here embmom BarbaraS

Posts.Content: embmom wrote: I just celebrated 5 years out from mets to the brain from triple negative cancer and almost 10 years out from original breast cancer, and today I find out I am her2positive with a new primary. After reading thru the forums for the her2+ group I just don't know if I can go thru this again. I have been fortunate to have had some really good years, have felt great and just recently expanded my business. I don't know if at 64 I can go thru taxoter again and a year of the herceptin. Reading thru the forums it looks like it is going to be a tough road and having done it all before I just don't know. I met with the surgeon today who is sending me back to the onc next week and is scheduling lots of scans to see if either of the cancers has spread. Just really bummed tonight. Dx 1/2008, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Stage 4 triple neg now her+ new primary embmom MommyErin

Posts.Content: embmom wrote: I'm so glad you all are here!  I have told friends and family and some of my customers about what's going on but other that that I really don't feel like talking about it much.  I've never really been sick before and never did like giving or getting too much information about illnesses. ( I keep thinking about my Brother-in-law's lengthy description of his diverticulitis problems at a family dinner)  But anyway I do keep reading all your conversations and how upbeat you more experienced ones are--this has really helped me and I'm sure others of us at the beginning of this crappy journey.  Right now  the really scary part is about what is coming and how I will cope .--I know its cancer because the surgeon already told me and this puppy in my boob is starting to look kinda nasty.  They actually have a term for women that put off finding out--I read it in the Dr. Love book the other night and even she said its not hopeless so I guess I'm not the only one who has done this.  One thing I am concerned about tho is giving up my business--I have built a retail business up the last couple of years into a really great business--my question is if I am going to be able to continue working  thru chemo?  I'm a pretty plucky strong thing that is used to working about 12 hours a day and I know that I won't be able to do that for awhile--but with lots of help do you think working thru chemo is doable?  I have real problems with depression so if I have to spend the next several months doing nothing at home but being sick things will go down hill very quickly.  Anyway thats just something I'm struggling with now--the same thing we all seem to worry about to some extent--this major change in our life.  My kids are grown now and this was supposed to be MY time--oh well--One funny thing I have noticed tho is when you tell someone you have breast cancer people immediately start telling you about all their health problems--after some of the stories bc doesn't look so bad! Thanks so much for being here!!! Dx 1/2008, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: just back from the biopsy embmom HeatherBLocklear

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2009 05:24PM embmom wrote: I had alot of trouble swallowing during rads--it started about the 3rd week and got so bad it was really difficult to eat.  I also had some gastric reflux problems.  They gave me some prilosec and some sort of anestetic type stuff to drink before I ate--that was disgusting-- They did say it was unusual but that it does happen during rads.  She did move the field abit--or at least said she did and eventually it went way after about 2 weeks.  Funny tho--I did show up with thyroid problems about 5 months later....hmmm..all the docs said they didn't do anything to cause it.  Well. I'm better now.   Good luck...like so many of the really aggravating SE's this too shall pass!
Posts.Title: Difficulty swallowing, a radiation side efffect? nanabolini yoga_girl
